publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l:
──Qui promittit Cives, Urbem, sibi Curæ,
Imperium fore, & Italiam, & delubra Deorum;
Quo patre sit natus, num ignotâ Matre inhonestus
Omnes Mortales curare & quærere cogit.
Tune Syri, Damæ, aut Dionysii filius, audes
Dejicere e Saxo Cives, aut tradere Cadmo?

Whoever promiseth (in the Senate) to take the City (of Rome\end·of·line·crowded\ & the Citizens under his care, nay the whole Empire, Italy, & the Temples of the Gods, such a man compells all Mortals curiously to enquire from what Father he sprung & whether his Mother were some Obscure dishonorable Female. (The People would cry out) What! thou the Son of \footnote·marker·here·refers·to·footnote·1,·to·follow\ Syrus, or \footnote·marker·here·refers·to·footnote·1,·to·follow\ Damas\end·of·line·tight\ or 1Usual Names of Slaves at Rome Dionysius, Dare you cast our Citizens down the Tarpeian Rock, or deliver them prisoners to 2Cadmus, was the Name of a Man who was a Lictor, an Officer who seized on Criminals, like our Constables or Messengers of the House of Commons── Cadmus──
A Paraphrase on the above Six Verses in Horace──
This wrote Apl 2d 1736.
If noisy Tom should in the Senate prate,
That he would answer both for Church & State;
And further to demonstrate his Affection,
Would take the Kingdom into his protection;
All Mortals must be curious to enquire,
Who could this Coxcomb be, & who his Sire.
What? thou the Spawn of him who sham'd our Isle?
That Traytor, Assassin, Informer vile?
Though by the Female Side you proudly bring
(To mend your breed) the Murderer of a King,
What was thy Grandsire but a Mountainneer,
Who held a Cabbin (at ten Groats a Year)
Whose Master Moore preserv'd him from the Halter
For stealing Cows, nor could have read the Psalter.
Durst thou, ungratefull, from the Senate Chace
Thy Founders Grandson, and usurp his place?
Iust Heaven! to see thy Dunghill Dastard Brood
Survive in thee, & make the ·Save a Theif &c─. Proverb good.
Thou vote a worthy Citizen to Iayl,
In spite of Iustice, & refuse his Bayl.
